-This document gives a comprehensive overview of the pros and cons of allowing privatization of a public service. icma.org/Documents/Document/Document/798

answers.author: Charles DeBow
answers.text:
Joseph,
The Borough of State College has one of the first parking operations based on the use of LPR in the country. All of our lates are pay by plate, our mobile payment platform uses LPR and we also do not have any physical permits. The license plate is your permit. 
http://www.genetec.com/about-us/news/press-center/press-releases/borough-of-state-college-pe-integrates-genetec-autovu-into-its-pay-by-plate-systems-one-of-the-countrys-first
Feel free to email/call me with any questions. 
As far as privatizing goes, its been done with great results and horrific results. Why pay a 3rd party to manage it for you?

author: Joseph Gacioch
text:
Ferndale has recently entered into an agreement with a company to operate our expanding digital parking system.  As an extension of this agreement, we are considering migrating parking enforcement over to them, as well as investing in license plate recognition technology to streamline and improve the enforcement process.
Are there any communities who can provide a synopsis of their experiences privatizing parking enforcement?  Do any communities have experience with transitioning to a LPR system, and can you speak of a corresponding return on investment?  What political or organizational barriers were faced when considering this transition and/or investment in upgrading enforcement technology?
I thank you for your feedback and input!
-Joe
title: Parking Enforcement Privatization
